abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for Kyrgyz Republic irrigation
            rehabilitation project were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the borrower
            performance was satisfactory. Lessons learned from the
            project: During implementation, the irrigation
            rehabilitation project management faced some difficulties in
            the selection of interventions that could be considered in
            the project. Considering the desire to deal with as many
            systems as possible, in some cases not all bottlenecks were
            removed from the systems. In countries in transition, time
            is essential. This project turned out to be very timely as
            it was urgent to reverse the deterioration of irrigation
            systems. Good supervision work is essential for satisfactory
            outcome. Besides the quality and commitment of the project
            implementation unit staff, the high quality and the
            continuity of the supervision missions was instrumental to
            the satisfactory implementation of the project.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Irrigation Rehabilitation Project
            aims at increasing the productivity of irrigated agriculture
            in the project area through improved water supply.  The
            project consists of three components.  i) Rehabilitation of
            irrigation infrastructure will support emergency repairs and
            selective low-cost rehabilitation of inter-farm irrigation
            infrastructure.  This includes the rehabilitation,
            completion, or improvement in monitoring systems of up to 12
            irrigation dams.  It will also support inter-farm canal
            networks to improve drainage.  ii) Capacity building will
            include implementation support of the Project Implementation
            Unit which handles the daily management, administration, and
            coordination of the project.  This component will also
            support institutional development by financing office
            equipment, machinery, software to assist oblast and rayon
            offices in the effective planning, operation, maintenance,
            and management of irrigation and dam systems.  It will also
            support various training activities and study tours.  iii)
            Incremental maintenance will assist with the financing of
            maintenance works for inter-farm irrigation infrastructure
            associated with the subprojects.

repnme.cdata!:
Kyrgyz Republic - Irrigation Rehabilitation
            Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Irrigation Rehabilitation Project
            aims to increase the productivity of irrigated agriculture
            in the project area through improved water supply and will
            constitute a six year program for irrigation rehabilitation.
            With regard to direct effects the mitigation program will
            particularly focus at the mitigation of poor construction
            practices. The designs will include the designs of properly
            landscaped silt deposits and the contractors for
            construction works will be obliged to remove all equipment
            and un-used construction materials after the works.
            Undesirably high levels of groundwater will be partially
            mitigated by improving drainage in some areas, which will
            also benefit health problems resulting from increased
            humidity in houses. Beyond that, this project is the first
            step in a series of projects, in which the increases in
            water use, inputs of agro-chemicals, waterlogging and
            salination, and erosion will be dealt with by the follow-up
            projects -- On-Farm Irrigation Project, Agricultural Support
            Services Project, Rural Credit Project, and the Sheep
            Project. It is recommended that all water quality and
            quantity issues will be dealt with under a comprehensive
            Integrated Water Management Action Plan identifying all
            water needs, their mutual interactions and opportunities.
